elements.content: Hierarchical structures of chiral coordination polymers based on Cu(I) and the C2-symmetric ligand, N,N ‘-bis(4-cyanophenyl)-(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane are presented. The polymer topologies, two-dimensional network in one case and three-dimensional architecture built up of three interwoven diamondoid structures in the other, arise from significant differences in the ligand conformations and modes of ligation. The impact of the structural motifs on the solid-state optical second harmonic generation capability is discussed.
elements.clean_text: Hierarchical structures of chiral coordination polymers based on Cu(I) and the C2-symmetric ligand, N,N ‘-bis(4-cyanophenyl)-(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane are presented. The polymer topologies, two-dimensional network in one case and three-dimensional architecture built up of three interwoven diamondoid structures in the other, arise from significant differences in the ligand conformations and modes of ligation. The impact of the structural motifs on the solid-state optical second harmonic generation capability is discussed.

elements.content: Cu(I) and the C 2-symmetric ligand, N,N ‘-bis(4-cyanophenyl)-(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane form coordination polymers with different ligand conformations and modes of ligation leading to two-dimensional network and three-dimensional interwoven diamondoid structures. Correlation between the SHG and structure of these materials is discussed.
elements.clean_text: Cu(I) and the C 2-symmetric ligand, N,N ‘-bis(4-cyanophenyl)-(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane form coordination polymers with different ligand conformations and modes of ligation leading to two-dimensional network and three-dimensional interwoven diamondoid structures. Correlation between the SHG and structure of these materials is discussed.

elements.content: The mode of assembly of molecules in crystals is strongly influenced by the nature of the intermolecular interactions. While in the case of small organic molecules and metal complexes these include primarily hydrogen-bond, dipolar, and dispersion interactions, in the case of coordination polymers, relatively stronger metal−ligand coordination are also involved in an extended fashion. One of the basic factors that leads to the occurrence of extensive cases of polymorphism in molecular crystals is the relatively low and comparable magnitudes of a range of intermolecular forces giving rise to a complex energy landscape representing varied patterns of molecular assemblies. The foregoing considerations imply that metal coordination polymers with a more robust structure are likely to show lower propensity toward polymorphic structures. This point has been noted in earlier work on structural/supramolecular isomerism in coordination polymers. The concept of supramolecular isomerism is a general one, and it has been pointed out that polymorphism should be viewed as a subset of supramolecular isomerism. In a less rigorous sense, structural variations arising from differences in the mode of ligation, ligand conformations, or both and in the network topologies have been described as cases of polymorphism. Coordination polymers are of considerable current interest because of a wide range of materials properties they exhibit. Since these properties are sensitively related to the supramolecular organization, and as noted above, the probability of polymorphism arising in these materials is relatively low, investigations of any occurrence of polymorphic or hierarchical structures and more significantly their correlation with materials attributes are valuable for the design of novel materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The mode of assembly of molecules in crystals is strongly influenced by the nature of the intermolecular interactions. While in the case of small organic molecules and metal complexes these include primarily hydrogen-bond, dipolar, and dispersion interactions, in the case of coordination polymers, relatively stronger metal-ligand coordination are also involved in an extended fashion. One of the basic factors that leads to the occurrence of extensive cases of polymorphism in molecular crystals is the relatively low and comparable magnitudes of a range of intermolecular forces giving rise to a complex energy landscape representing varied patterns of molecular assemblies. The foregoing considerations imply that metal coordination polymers with a more robust structure are likely to show lower propensity toward polymorphic structures. This point has been noted in earlier work on structural/supramolecular isomerism in coordination polymers. The concept of supramolecular isomerism is a general one, and it has been pointed out that polymorphism should be viewed as a subset of supramolecular isomerism. In a less rigorous sense, structural variations arising from differences in the mode of ligation, ligand conformations, or both and in the network topologies have been described as cases of polymorphism. Coordination polymers are of considerable current interest because of a wide range of materials properties they exhibit. Since these properties are sensitively related to the supramolecular organization, and as noted above, the probability of polymorphism arising in these materials is relatively low, investigations of any occurrence of polymorphic or hierarchical structures and more significantly their correlation with materials attributes are valuable for the design of novel materials.

elements.content: We have reported recently the formation of coordination polymers of Ag(I) and Cu(I) with N,N ‘-bis(4-cyanophenyl)-(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane (BCDC), which serves as a novel push−pull ligand. It was shown that the mode of metal coordination and polymer topology strongly influence the solid-state second harmonic generation (SHG) of these materials with respect to the free ligand. BCDC has multiple ligation sites and showed different conformations in the two complexes. Since Cu(I) generally shows tetrahedral coordination, we anticipated that the Cu(I)−BCDC complex may be amenable to different structural organizations in the solid state. The crystal we reported earlier was grown at the interface of dichloromethane and THF by taking [Cu(CH3CN)4]PF6 and BCDC in the two layers respectively; the formula unit of this crystal is [Cu(BCDC)]PF6·THF. Now we have carried out the synthesis by mixing the precursors in pure dichloromethane and have obtained a new structure of the Cu(I)−BCDC complex free of THF, with the formula, [Cu(BCDC)2]PF6. We describe in this paper the very different coordination modes and ligand conformations in [Cu(BCDC)]PF6·THF (CBPT) and [Cu(BCDC)2]PF6 (CBP) leading to the hierarchical structures, a two-dimensional network in the former and a three-dimensional architecture built up of interwoven diamondoid networks in the latter. Diamondoid networks possess the connectivity of a diamond lattice, but the local symmetry at the vertices may not be strictly T d ; SHG active materials have been developed based on noncentric interwoven diamondoid structures. CBPT and CBP could be described as dimorphic structures, following earlier reports of polymorphic forms with focus on the metal−ligand combination rather than on the specific stoichiometry or ligand structure. More significantly, the consequence of the hierarchy in these noncentrosymmetric structures for their solid-state optical SHG capability is explored.
elements.clean_text: We have reported recently the formation of coordination polymers of Ag(I) and Cu(I) with N,N ‘-bis(4-cyanophenyl)-(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane (BCDC), which serves as a novel push-pull ligand. It was shown that the mode of metal coordination and polymer topology strongly influence the solid-state second harmonic generation (SHG) of these materials with respect to the free ligand. BCDC has multiple ligation sites and showed different conformations in the two complexes. Since Cu(I) generally shows tetrahedral coordination, we anticipated that the Cu(I)-BCDC complex may be amenable to different structural organizations in the solid state. The crystal we reported earlier was grown at the interface of dichloromethane and THF by taking [Cu(CH3CN)4]PF6 and BCDC in the two layers respectively; the formula unit of this crystal is [Cu(BCDC)]PF6⋅THF. Now we have carried out the synthesis by mixing the precursors in pure dichloromethane and have obtained a new structure of the Cu(I)-BCDC complex free of THF, with the formula, [Cu(BCDC)2]PF6. We describe in this paper the very different coordination modes and ligand conformations in [Cu(BCDC)]PF6⋅THF (CBPT) and [Cu(BCDC)2]PF6 (CBP) leading to the hierarchical structures, a two-dimensional network in the former and a three-dimensional architecture built up of interwoven diamondoid networks in the latter. Diamondoid networks possess the connectivity of a diamond lattice, but the local symmetry at the vertices may not be strictly T  d ; SHG active materials have been developed based on noncentric interwoven diamondoid structures. CBPT and CBP could be described as dimorphic structures, following earlier reports of polymorphic forms with focus on the metal-ligand combination rather than on the specific stoichiometry or ligand structure. More significantly, the consequence of the hierarchy in these noncentrosymmetric structures for their solid-state optical SHG capability is explored.

elements.content: Syntheses of BCDC as well as CBPT have been communicated by us earlier; synthesis of BCDC by an alternate route has also been reported by Kwit and Gawronski. Details of the synthesis and characterization of CBPT and CBP are provided below.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Syntheses of BCDC as well as CBPT have been communicated by us earlier; synthesis of BCDC by an alternate route has also been reported by Kwit and Gawronski. Details of the synthesis and characterization of CBPT and CBP are provided below.

elements.content: [Cu(BCDC)]PF 6 ·THF. 0.08 g (0.26 mmol) of BCDC in THF was layered on a solution of 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of [Cu(CH3CN)4]PF6 in dry dichloromethane. Colorless crystals formed in about 48 h. The solution was decanted and the crystals were washed with dichloromethane and THF and dried. Yield: 0.13 g (80%). m.p./°C = 205 (dec); FT-IR (KBr):  υ/cm-1 = 3414.3, 2243.4, 1597.2, 1506.5, 843.0; UV−Vis (solid pellet; reflectance mode): λmax/nm = 275.6, 362.2.
elements.clean_text: [Cu(BCDC)]PF  6  ⋅THF. 0.08 g (0.26 mmol) of BCDC in THF was layered on a solution of 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of [Cu(CH3CN)4]PF6 in dry dichloromethane. Colorless crystals formed in about 48 h. The solution was decanted and the crystals were washed with dichloromethane and THF and dried. Yield: 0.13 g (80%). m.p./°C = 205 (dec); FT-IR (KBr): υ/cm-1 = 3414.3, 2243.4,  1597.2, 1506.5, 843.0; UV-Vis (solid pellet; reflectance mode): λmax/nm = 275.6, 362.2.

elements.content: [Cu(BCDC) 2 ]PF 6 . 0.08 g (0.26 mmol) of BCDC in dry dichloromethane was slowly added to a solution of 0.05 g (0.13 mmol) of [Cu(CH3CN)4]PF6 in dry dichloromethane. Colorless crystals formed in about 2−3 days. The crystals were removed and washed with dichloromethane and dried. Yield: 0.10 g (89%). m.p./°C = 170 (dec); FT-IR (KBr):  υ/cm-1 = 3406.6, 2233.7, 1602.9, 1510.4, 846.8; UV−Vis (solid pellet; reflectance mode): λmax/nm = 263.5, 334.4.
elements.clean_text: [Cu(BCDC)  2  ]PF  6  . 0.08 g (0.26 mmol) of BCDC in dry dichloromethane was slowly added to a solution of 0.05 g (0.13 mmol) of [Cu(CH3CN)4]PF6 in dry dichloromethane. Colorless crystals formed in about 2-3 days. The crystals were removed and washed with dichloromethane and dried. Yield: 0.10 g (89%). m.p./°C = 170 (dec); FT-IR (KBr): υ/cm-1 = 3406.6, 2233.7, 1602.9, 1510.4, 846.8; UV-Vis (solid pellet; reflectance mode): λmax/nm = 263.5, 334.4.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data were collected either on an Enraf-Nonius MACH3 diffractometer or on a Bruker Nonius Smart Apex diffractometer (with CCD detector). Mo Kα radiation with a graphite crystal monochromator in the incident beam was used. Data were reduced using Xtal3.4 or SAINT. All non-hydrogen atoms were found using the direct method analysis in SHELX-97 or SHELXTL and after several cycles of refinement the positions of the hydrogen atoms were calculated and added to the refinement process. The Flack parameter was refined in both cases. Details of data collection, solution, and refinement, as well as the crystallographic information files are available as Supplementary Information. SHG from microcrystalline powders was examined using the Kurtz-Perry method; details of the procedure may be found elsewhere.
elements.clean_text: X-ray diffraction data were collected either on an Enraf-Nonius MACH3 diffractometer or on a Bruker Nonius Smart Apex diffractometer (with CCD detector). Mo Kα radiation with a graphite crystal monochromator in the incident beam was used. Data were reduced using Xtal3.4 or SAINT. All non-hydrogen atoms were found using the direct method analysis in SHELX-97 or SHELXTL and after several cycles of refinement the positions of the hydrogen atoms were calculated and added to the refinement process. The Flack parameter was refined in both cases. Details of data collection, solution, and refinement, as well as the crystallographic information files are available as Supplementary Information. SHG from microcrystalline powders was examined using the Kurtz-Perry method; details of the procedure may be found elsewhere.

elements.content: The basic crystallographic data of CBPT and CBP are summarized in Table . These crystals belong to the orthorhombic space groups, P22121 and P212121, respectively. Figure illustrates the different coordination modes and conformations of BCDC units around Cu(I) in the two crystals. In CBPT, Cu(I) shows tetrahedral coordination with two amino nitrogen atoms of one BCDC and one cyano nitrogen atom each from two other BCDC molecules. The conformation of the cyanophenyl groups in BCDC may be characterized by the torsion angle, τ, formed by the phenyl carbon (C8), amino nitrogen (N3), the stereogenic carbon to which the amino group is attached (C5) and the other stereogenic carbon (C5‘). The value of τ in free BCDC is 157.9°, indicating an exo conformation. In CBPT, the BCDC retains this exo conformation to accommodate the Cu(I) coordination at the amino sites and the τ is 164.9°. In the case of CBP, four BCDC ligands are coordinated tetrahedrally to Cu(I) through one cyano nitrogen atom from each. Two of the BCDCs are in exo conformation (τ = 161.0°) and the other two in endo conformation (τ = 93.1°) (since the BCDCs are close to, but not exactly, C 2 symmetric, these τ are average values). The significant bond lengths in the two crystals listed in Table show values typical of Cu(I)−cyano and Cu(I)−amino coordination. It is seen that the local symmetry at the metal in CBP is close to, but not exactly, T d .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The basic crystallographic data of CBPT and CBP are summarized in Table . These crystals belong to the orthorhombic space groups, P22121 and P212121, respectively. Figure  illustrates the different coordination modes and conformations of BCDC units around Cu(I) in the two crystals. In CBPT, Cu(I) shows tetrahedral coordination with two amino nitrogen atoms of one BCDC and one cyano nitrogen atom each from two other BCDC molecules. The conformation of the cyanophenyl groups in BCDC may be characterized by the torsion angle, τ, formed by the phenyl carbon (C8), amino nitrogen (N3), the stereogenic carbon to which the amino group is attached (C5) and the other stereogenic carbon (C5‘). The value of τ in free BCDC is 157.9°, indicating an exo conformation. In CBPT, the BCDC retains this exo conformation to accommodate the Cu(I) coordination at the amino sites and the τ is 164.9°. In the case of CBP, four BCDC ligands are coordinated tetrahedrally to Cu(I) through one cyano nitrogen atom from each. Two of the BCDCs are in exo conformation (τ = 161.0°) and the other two in endo conformation (τ = 93.1°) (since the BCDCs are close to, but not exactly, C 2 symmetric, these τ are average values). The significant bond lengths in the two crystals listed in Table  show values typical of Cu(I)-cyano and Cu(I)-amino coordination. It is seen that the local symmetry at the metal in CBP is close to, but not exactly, T  d .

elements.content: Coordination of BCDC around Cu(I) in (a) CBPT and (b) CBP. Atom labeling is indicated; hydrogen atoms, PF6 - ion, and THF are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination of BCDC around Cu(I) in (a) CBPT and (b) CBP. Atom labeling is indicated; hydrogen atoms, PF6 - ion, and THF are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
Crystallographic Data for CBPT and CBP

Significant Bond Lengths and Angles in (a) CBPT and (b) CBP a

bond/bonds distance (Å)/angle (°) (a) CBPT Cu1−N3‘ 2.213(6) Cu1−N3‘ ‘ 2.213(6) Cu1−N4 1.897(6) Cu1−N4‘ 1.897(6) N4−C14 1.124(8) N4‘−C14‘ 1.124(8) N3‘−Cu1−N3‘ ‘ 79.0(3) N3‘−Cu1−N4 106.8(2) N3‘−Cu1−N4‘ 107.3(2) N3‘ ‘−Cu1−N4 107.3(2) N3‘ ‘−Cu1−N4‘ 106.8(2) N4−Cu1−N4‘ 135.2(4) (b) CBP Cu1−N1‘ 1.986(3) Cu1−N2‘ 1.981(3) Cu1−N3 1.980(3) Cu1−N4 1.979(3) N1−C9 1.131(5) N2−C16 1.148(4) N3−C47 1.142(5) N4−C48 1.140(5) N1‘−Cu1−N2‘ 102.43(12) N1‘−Cu1−N3 112.64(15) N1‘−Cu1−N4 113.42(15) N2‘−Cu1−N3 110.50(15) N2‘−Cu1−N4 115.93(15) N3−Cu1−N4 102.29(18)

a See Figure for atom labeling.

The extended structures of the coordination polymers are also grossly different in the two crystals. As reported earlier, CBPT shows two-dimensional networks with the PF6 - counterion and the included THF molecule residing in the pores of the network (Figure ). The amino groups of the BCDC are engaged in hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atom of the THF. The structure of CBP is shown in Figure . In this structure, the PF6 - ions as well as the cyano groups of BCDC form hydrogen bonds with the amino groups of the BCDC leading to extended structures. Comparison of the structures of CBPT and CBP shows that the presence of THF in the crystallization medium has led to its inclusion in the structure of CBPT and considerable variation in the conformation of BCDC and ligation around Cu(I). The net impact may be visualized in terms of the network topology arising in CBPT and CBP. Figure provides a schematic representation of the two-dimensional rhombus network in CBPT; the BCDC (in exo conformation) connecting the Cu(I) sites are represented using straight lines, the Cu(I)···Cu(I) distances being 9.467 Å. The topology of CBP is more fascinating. The tetrahedrally coordinated BCDCs around the Cu(I) sites lead to a two-dimensional architecture which can be described as an interwoven structure of three diamondoid networks (Figure ). There is a succession of layers, constituted of six-member rings in elongated chair conformation, from each of the diamondoid networks; the interconnections between the layers are also elongated. The Cu(I)···Cu(I) distances within the layer are 10.406 and 18.148 Å and that between the layers is 18.148 Å; the short and long distances correspond respectively to the bridging BCDC in endo and exo conformations. An alternate way to visualize the structure of CBP is as a combination of helical formations involving Cu(I) and BCDC ligands in different directions. Helices along the c axis are built up of exo and endo BCDC ligands alternating along each chain, and 21 chains along the a and b axes are built through exo and endo ligands respectively (Figure ).

As reported earlier, CBPT shows two-dimensional networks with the PF6 - counterion and the included THF molecule residing in the pores of the network (Figure ). The amino groups of the BCDC are engaged in hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atom of the THF. The structure of CBP is shown in Figure . In this structure, the PF6 - ions as well as the cyano groups of BCDC form hydrogen bonds with the amino groups of the BCDC leading to extended structures. Comparison of the structures of CBPT and CBP shows that the presence of THF in the crystallization medium has led to its inclusion in the structure of CBPT and considerable variation in the conformation of BCDC and ligation around Cu(I). The net impact may be visualized in terms of the network topology arising in CBPT and CBP. Figure  provides a schematic representation of the two-dimensional rhombus network in CBPT; the BCDC (in exo conformation) connecting the Cu(I) sites are represented using straight lines, the Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅Cu(I) distances being 9.467 Å. The topology of CBP is more fascinating. The tetrahedrally coordinated BCDCs around the Cu(I) sites lead to a two-dimensional architecture which can be described as an interwoven structure of three diamondoid networks  (Figure ). The Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅Cu(I) distances within the layer are 10.406 and 18.148 Å and that between the layers is 18.148 Å; the short and long distances correspond respectively to the bridging BCDC in endo and exo conformations. An alternate way to visualize the structure of CBP is as a combination of helical formations involving Cu(I) and BCDC ligands in different directions. Helices along the c axis are built up of exo and endo BCDC ligands alternating along each chain, and 21 chains along the a and b axes are built through exo and endo ligands respectively (Figure ).

The orange spheres represent Cu(I), the blue spheres, the cyano nitrogen atoms, and the green and white spheres the amino nitrogen atoms; the nitrogen atoms with the connecting lines denote the BCDC ligand. The green and white nitrogen atoms relate to BCDC in exo and endo conformations, respectively.

The green and white nitrogen atoms relate to BCDC in exo and endo conformations, respectively.

elements.content: The chirality associated with the coordination polymers ensures noncentrosymmetric solid-state organization. This factor coupled with the push−pull nature of the BCDC−metal ion combination suggests potential second-order nonlinear optical effects in these materials. In our earlier study, we have explored the impact of the metal ion coordination on the optical SHG capability of BCDC. CBPT shows a solid-state SHG, 0.2 times that of urea. Repeated experiments22 with CBP showed that it has no measurable SHG. Some insight into the difference of SHG between CBPT and CBP may be obtained by considering the different coordination modes and local metal−ligand structure as well as the very different network topologies in the two structures.
elements.clean_text: The chirality associated with the coordination polymers ensures noncentrosymmetric solid-state organization. This factor coupled with the push-pull nature of the BCDC-metal ion combination suggests potential second-order nonlinear optical effects in these materials. In our earlier study, we have explored the impact of the metal ion coordination on the optical SHG capability of BCDC. CBPT shows a solid-state SHG, 0.2 times that of urea. Repeated experiments22 with CBP showed that it has no measurable SHG. Some insight into the difference of SHG between CBPT and CBP may be obtained by considering the different coordination modes and local metal-ligand structure as well as the very different network topologies in the two structures.

elements.content: The investigation of Ag(I) and Cu(I) polymers of BCDC15 had indicated that the SHG of these materials is primarily controlled by the ligand conformation and the mode of metal coordination, and not so much affected by the specific metal itself. Along similar lines as reported earlier, we have carried out semiempirical AM1/TDHF computations to assess the relative magnitudes of the static hyperpolarizability (β0) of BCDC as present in the coordination polymers. The molecular structures from crystal structure were used with hydrogen atom positions alone optimized in the computation. Metal ions were replaced by point charges, since the program does not have suitable parameters for Cu(I) and we are primarily interested in the effect of the positive charge as stated above. The BCDC in CBPT influenced by the three charges placed at the Cu(I) sites has been shown to possess a β0 of 3.85 × 10-30 esu. CBP contains two types of BCDC with two Cu(I) attached to the cyano nitrogens. The computations showed that the exo and endo forms possess, respectively, β0 values 14.17 × 10-30 and 21.66 × 10-30 esu. The higher β0 of endo conformation compared to that of the exo conformation and the enhancement and reduction of β0 on attachment of positive charge at the cyano and amino sites respectively are consistent with the classical concept of push−pull molecules. Despite the higher hyperpolarizability of the units in the polymer, CBP shows no observable SHG. This points to the possible impact of the mode of coordination around the metal ion and the resulting connectivity and network topology. The asymmetric nature of ligation around Cu(I) in CBPT gives it appreciable dipolar character, whereas the corresponding unit in CBP can be described formally as an octupolar system even though the dipolar component does not strictly vanish. The potential utility of octupolar systems in quadratic NLO applications was first highlighted by the seminal work of Zyss, wherein a systematic appraisal of the dipolar/octupolar contributions to the nonlinear response of molecules and materials was presented. Large hyperpolarizabilities have since then been demonstrated in octupolar molecules. At the bulk level, SHG has been obtained in polymer films with optically oriented octupolar molecules as well as a host of two- and three-dimensional coordination polymers based on octupolar building blocks. The fundamental question of optimal molecular organization that would lead to enhanced bulk nonlinearity has been addressed in the case of dipolar systems early on, and for the two-dimensional octupolar systems more recently. In the present study, it appears that the evolution from a two-dimensional organization in CBPT to a three-dimensional one in CBP has had an adverse impact on the SHG capability. If the considerably higher SHG of the Ag(I) polymer with a one-dimensional helical motif15 is also taken into account, a correlation emerges between the dimensionality of the network topology and the nonlinear optical response; in this family of coordination polymers based on BCDC, lower dimensionality is more favorable. The structure around the metal, dipolar in CBPT, octupolar in CBP, and linear and nonpolar in the Ag(I) polymer, does not appear to have a direct correlation to the observed SHG. It is pertinent to note that mutually orthogonal helical motifs leading to three-dimensionally connected structures have been found to exhibit relatively lower SHG capability than helical superstructures formed along a single crystallographic direction, in polymorphs of an organic molecular crystal. These arguments provide a framework to visualize the difference in the solid-state SHG capability of CBPT and CBP in the context of the hierarchy in their network structural motifs. However, in view of the discussion of optimal organization of dipolar and octupolar systems referred to above, cognizance should be taken of the fact that neither of the individual structures of two- and three-dimensional networks in the present study have been optimized through any systematic approach. Hence, exploration of several more families of polymorphic systems is essential to test the generality of the present observations.

Along similar lines as reported earlier, we have carried out semiempirical AM1/TDHF computations to assess the relative magnitudes of the static hyperpolarizability (β0) of BCDC as present in the coordination polymers. The molecular structures from crystal structure were used with hydrogen atom positions alone optimized in the computation. Metal ions were replaced by point charges, since the program does not have suitable parameters for  Cu(I) and we are primarily interested in the effect of the positive charge as stated above. The BCDC in CBPT influenced by the three charges placed at the Cu(I) sites has been shown to possess a β0 of 3.85 × 10-30 esu. CBP contains two types of BCDC with two Cu(I) attached to the cyano nitrogens. The computations showed that the exo and endo forms possess, respectively, β0 values 14.17 × 10-30 and 21.66 × 10-30 esu. The higher β0 of endo conformation compared to that of the exo conformation and the enhancement and reduction of β0 on attachment of positive charge at the cyano and amino sites respectively are consistent with the classical concept of push-pull molecules. Despite the higher hyperpolarizability of the units in the polymer, CBP shows no observable SHG. This points to the possible impact of the mode of coordination around the metal ion and the resulting connectivity and network topology. The asymmetric nature of ligation around Cu(I) in CBPT gives it appreciable dipolar character, whereas the corresponding unit in CBP can be described formally as an octupolar system even though the dipolar component does not strictly vanish. The potential utility of octupolar systems in quadratic NLO applications was first highlighted by the seminal work of Zyss, wherein a systematic appraisal of the dipolar/octupolar contributions to the nonlinear response of molecules and materials was presented. Large hyperpolarizabilities have since then been demonstrated in octupolar molecules. At the bulk level, SHG has been obtained in polymer films with optically oriented octupolar molecules as well as a host of two- and three-dimensional coordination polymers based on octupolar building blocks. The fundamental question of optimal molecular organization that would lead to enhanced bulk nonlinearity has been addressed in the case of dipolar systems early on, and for the two-dimensional octupolar systems more recently. In the present study, it appears that the evolution from a two-dimensional organization in CBPT to a three-dimensional one in CBP has had an adverse impact on the SHG capability. If the considerably higher SHG of the Ag(I) polymer with a one-dimensional helical motif15 is also taken into account, a correlation emerges between the dimensionality of the network topology and the nonlinear optical response; in this family of coordination polymers based on BCDC, lower dimensionality is more favorable. The structure around the metal, dipolar in CBPT, octupolar in CBP, and linear and nonpolar in the Ag(I) polymer, does not appear to have a direct correlation to the observed SHG. It is pertinent to note that mutually orthogonal helical motifs leading to three-dimensionally connected structures have been found to exhibit relatively lower SHG capability than helical superstructures formed along a single crystallographic direction, in polymorphs of an organic molecular crystal. These arguments provide a framework to visualize the difference in the solid-state SHG capability of CBPT and CBP in the context of the hierarchy in their network structural motifs. However, in view of the discussion of optimal organization of dipolar and octupolar systems referred to above, cognizance should be taken of the fact that neither of the individual structures of two- and three-dimensional networks in the present study have been optimized through any systematic approach. Hence, exploration of several more families of polymorphic systems is essential to test the generality of the present observations.

elements.content: The utility of an axially chiral ligand we have recently described, in the formation of isomeric forms of Cu(I) coordination polymer, is reported in this paper. The structures of the Cu(I)−BCDC complex arising as a result of the difference in the crystallization solvent manifest clearly different conformations of the ligand, modes of ligation, and polymer network topologies. The consequence of the hierarchical structures, two-dimensional network, and three-dimensional diamondoid for the solid-state SHG of the two forms is discussed. It would be interesting to explore the combination of this versatile and simple ligand with other metal ions and also examine the correlation between the network topology and nonlinear optical response in coordination polymers in general.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The utility of an axially chiral ligand we have recently described, in the formation of isomeric forms of Cu(I) coordination polymer, is reported in this paper. The structures of the Cu(I)-BCDC complex arising as a result of the difference in the crystallization solvent  manifest clearly different conformations of the ligand, modes of ligation, and polymer network topologies. The consequence of the hierarchical structures, two-dimensional network, and three-dimensional diamondoid for the solid-state SHG of the two forms is discussed. It would be interesting to explore the combination of this versatile and simple ligand with other metal ions and also examine the correlation between the network topology and nonlinear optical response in coordination polymers in general.

cln_elements.content:
[Cu(BCDC)]PF 6 ·THF. 0.08 g (0.26 mmol) of BCDC in THF was layered on a solution of 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of [Cu(CH3CN)4]PF6 in dry dichloromethane. Colorless crystals formed in about 48 h. The solution was decanted and the crystals were washed with dichloromethane and THF and dried. Yield: 0.13 g (80%). m.p./°C = 205 (dec); FT-IR (KBr):  υ/cm-1 = 3414.3, 2243.4, 1597.2, 1506.5, 843.0; UV−Vis (solid pellet; reflectance mode): λmax/nm = 275.6, 362.2.

[Cu(BCDC) 2 ]PF 6 . 0.08 g (0.26 mmol) of BCDC in dry dichloromethane was slowly added to a solution of 0.05 g (0.13 mmol) of [Cu(CH3CN)4]PF6 in dry dichloromethane. Colorless crystals formed in about 2−3 days. The crystals were removed and washed with dichloromethane and dried. Yield: 0.10 g (89%). m.p./°C = 170 (dec); FT-IR (KBr):  υ/cm-1 = 3406.6, 2233.7, 1602.9, 1510.4, 846.8; UV−Vis (solid pellet; reflectance mode): λmax/nm = 263.5, 334.4.

cln_elements.content: Schematic diagram of the helical formations in CBP along (a)a, (b) b, and (c) c axes. The orange spheres represent Cu(I), the blue spheres, the cyano nitrogen atoms, and the green and white spheres the amino nitrogen atoms; the nitrogen atoms with the connecting lines denote the BCDC ligand. The green and white nitrogen atoms relate to BCDC in exo and endo conformations, respectively.

metadata.title:
Coordination Polymers of Cu(I) with a Chiral Push−Pull
Ligand:  Hierarchical Network Structures and Second
Harmonic Generation
